oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: So, item 2, then, today is our first session on the provision of textbooks and learning resources for pupils, which is a video of interviews with young people and teachers.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: Shall I start?

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: So, Qualifications Wales is the regulator of the awarding bodies, so we regulate awarding bodies.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: That said, when we are going through the design of the qualifications, we go through an approval process, so we develop approval criteria and we ask WJEC to submit their specifications against those approval criteria and sample assessment materials as well.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: The WJEC does provide what's required in a regulatory sense, and there are two things there—the specification, which tends to be very comprehensive in providing guidance in terms of drawing up a programme of teaching, and also exemplar assessments, which include marking, and those go to the regulator before they are published.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: The WJEC also do invest a great deal in resources that we produce digitally in both languages simultaneously.

oracle_info.speaker: Mike Ebbsworth
oracle_info.content: At the end of the process, then, the publishers in England have agreed to hold the English version back for a period of time until the Welsh version is available, and then to publish both simultaneously.

oracle_info.speaker: Mike Ebbsworth
oracle_info.content: But that's the hope: that when new textbooks are produced in English and authored in English, we would look at that eight-week period as a turnaround.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: Every young person in Wales, I would hope, taking GCSE or A-level, should have that digital literacy in order to source the valuable materials available—that they should have those skills.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: Ideally, resources, digital accessibility and digital literacy should be available for every pupil on an equal basis.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: So, I think your question drives at a very important point: what sort of inequality could be having an impact on young people in terms of their achievement during their school time?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: We can't disagree that there's evidence of stress, but I think we can also point towards resilience and excellent approaches to drawing together the various sources that they've got: classroom notes, revision notes, as they mentioned, and the various other materials that they referred to.

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: Just on this issue of shaping the curriculum and making sure that we've got textbooks that can be used to support the delivery of the curriculum—.

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: So, obviously, the WJEC's interested in the examinations and the qualifications.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: They have responsibility for curriclum and they've already started work with the seminar last year, and then drawing people together now to look at a new model for the future.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize the role of Qualification Wales, according to Philip Blaker.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: So, Qualifications Wales is the regulator of the awarding bodies, so we regulate awarding bodies.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: In regulating the awarding body, our primary focus is also on the design of the qualifications and then the delivery of the assessment.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: Our other primary role is in maintaining standards.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: So, as the regulator of qualifications, what we want to do is we want to make that the awards of qualifications—so, the grades that people get—are fair.

oracle_info.speaker: Philip Blaker
oracle_info.content: During a period of change, we prescribe the use of comparable outcomes as the primary approach, largely because comparable outcomes are designed for circumstances like this, where there's a change in a specification particularly, because there are any number of reasons, including resources, why performance may be different from one year to the next, but comparable outcomes is there to ensure that, all things being equal, if the cohorts have the same ability, the same grade should be awarded from one year to the next.

specific_query_list.query: What did Gareth Pierce think of the translation of materials between the two languages?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: The Welsh language, of course, is a language that is used in an educational context, but we are in a big world that's an English language world.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: I'm very aware that many of the websites we refer to in our resources and many of the case studies, as was mentioned in that video—they are available in English only.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: And, certainly, it would be very unfortunate if there were a dozen Welsh-medium schools, for example, translating material from the same website independently of each other.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: I'm sure that some teachers feel that there is a way of enriching the teaching by referring to terms in both languages, as well as explaining those terms in their own language.

specific_query_list.query: Why did Darren Millar AM disagree about WJEC's approaches to textbooks?

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: It's a huge mess, which is causing lots of pressure and extra work for teachers, lots of pressure and extra work for learners, and is affecting the well-being of students, at a time when they need to be mentally fit, in order to go through the general stress that learners face when they have exams coming up.

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: But isn't a textbook a pretty basic element of anybody's toolkit for supporting a child getting through the information that they need to learn, and swot up on, in advance of exams?

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: You mentioned digital resources; not everybody's got access to digital resources in their own homes, even, in Wales.

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: So, aren't we giving a significant disadvantage to those learners who might need the traditional 'swotting up from a textbook' method of revision and benefit from that?

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: Can I just ask you about the disadvantage that some learners might face as a result of the lack of textbooks?

specific_query_list.query: How did the WJEC tackle the concerns raised by Darren Millar AM?

oracle_info.speaker: Mike Ebbsworth
oracle_info.content: We do ensure that those digital resources include things that the teachers can also print.

oracle_info.speaker: Mike Ebbsworth
oracle_info.content: Most of these are resources for teachers so that the teachers can adapt them for their own use, to suit the learners who are in front of them at any given time.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: The young people talk about websites and blogs, and we're talking about digital resources, so being able to reach those resources, I think, is vital in Wales.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: So, the flexibility for the pupil is very important, I think.

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: I understand that, but I've got people in my constituency who haven't even got a broadband link at home, so there's a digital disadvantage as well.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: I think also, perhaps, related to that, it is important to mention digital literacy here.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: Every young person in Wales, I would hope, taking GCSE or A-level, should have that digital literacy in order to source the valuable materials available—that they should have those skills.

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: Can I just ask you about the disadvantage that some learners might face as a result of the lack of textbooks?

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: But, how do you differentiate between the different learning styles of individual students who are in that cohort to ensure that the disadvantage that one faces because they're somebody who relies particularly heavily on textbook-type learning, traditional sort of swotting up for examinations, versus someone who is much more digitally aware and able to use digital resources—?

specific_query_list.query: What did Gareth Pierce talk about the subsidy in developing materials bilingually?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: Our view in the WJEC is that subsidy will be necessary.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: Why not rethink that and think of a subsidy for producing resources in two languages for the Welsh curriculum?

specific_query_list.query: What was the decision of WJEC to reduce the delay between materials having an English version and a Welsh version?

oracle_info.speaker: Mike Ebbsworth
oracle_info.content: At the end of the process, then, the publishers in England have agreed to hold the English version back for a period of time until the Welsh version is available, and then to publish both simultaneously.

specific_query_list.query: Why was the council disagree about WJEC's decision to delay the Welsh/English version?

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: But to suggest that you will delay books that could be available for students and could be available for teachers to be able to access by two months because you haven't got the systems in place to be able to produce them on the same day, seems to be wholly inappropriate.

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: And, as the Chair said, is that about putting those students in Wales on the same footing, and if so, how does that relate to the fact that these students, including those who could have had earlier access to the English-language version, are competing with students over the border, as we heard on the video earlier, for those precious university places?

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: Doesn't it place the English-language student using the English-language version at a potential disadvantage, compared to students over the border?

specific_query_list.query: What did Gareth Pierce think of the digital inequalities as a kind of unfairness?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: But I think perhaps if we analysed this in much detail, different individuals would be able to say, 'There are different types of unfairness.'

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: So, I think your question drives at a very important point: what sort of inequality could be having an impact on young people in terms of their achievement during their school time?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: So, I don't think I can go any further than acknowledging that any inequality is unfair, but there are so many different kinds and the textbook is not the only one, and therefore we're not going to be able to analyse the impact of that on its own.

specific_query_list.query: According to Gareth Pierce, how did they develop the pupils' skills to analyse and combine information into a discursive argument?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: We do draw on a body of expertise, and we are more than willing to emphasise the importance of that approach to the support resources we provide.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: They would be described as scholarly, and I think some of the young people on the video made that point, didn't they—that they need to engage with that material to understand some themes?

specific_query_list.query: How did WJEC respond to the criticisms from Estyn about the materials?

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: Again, probably, I'd like a conversation with them about any problems with the specimen assessments and their mark schemes, because if they are the statutory regulatory ones they would have gone through Philip's team as well or his Welsh Government predecessors as regulators, depending on which qualifications they were.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: We have met with Estyn a couple of times recently, actually—once when they were beginning their review of the key stage 4 qualifications that had been in place for two years and a bit, and also when they were planning a review of some of the A-level work.

oracle_info.speaker: Gareth Pierce
oracle_info.content: But, yes, I agree with their fundamental premise, that ideally the whole package of resources should be available before teaching starts, including, as we mentioned earlier, so we can draw on that set of resources in the events we run as WJEC free of charge for teachers leading up to the first teaching.
